Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 : A Heterogeneous, Eco-friendly and Reusable Catalyst for the Solvent-Free Catalytic Preparation of 1,1-Diacetates from Aldehydes Razieh FAZAELI*, Hamid ALIYAN* Department of Chemistry, Islamic Azad University, Shahreza Branch 86145-311, Shahreza, Iran Abstract: Aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes were transformed to 1,1-diacetates (acylals) under mild conditions by treatment with acetic anhydride and Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 catalyst. This catalyst was efficient for the preparation of 1,1-diacetate under solvent-free conditions. The reverse reaction using the resulting 1,1-diacetate was achieved using the same catalyst in acetonitrile as a solvent. This new method has the advantages of excellent yields and short reaction time. The catalyst can be reused several times although it gets less active. Key words: heteropoly acid; polyoxometalate; aldehyde; 1,1-diacetate; supported catalyst The conventional method available for the preparation of 1,1-diacetates involves the reaction of aldehydes with acetic anhydride using a strong acids (such as sulfuric, phosphoric, and methanesulfonic acids [1]), solid acidic materials [2–5], Lewis acids (such as iodine [6], trimethylchlorosilane, and sodium iodide [7]), FeCl 3 [8–10], FeSO 4 [11], phosphorus trichloride [12], indium trichloride [13], Sc(OTf) 3 [14], Cu(OTf) 2 [15], Bi(OTf) 3 [16], LiOTf [17], and In(OTf) 3 [18]. Montmorillonite clay [19–20], expansive graphite [21], zeo- lites [22–24], N-bromosuccinimide [25], ceric ammonium nitrate [26], NH 2 SO 3 H [27], WCl 6 [28], AlPW 12 O 40 [29], H 6 P 2 W 18 O 62 ·24H 2 O [30], zirconium sulfophenyl phosphonate [31], ZrCl 4 [32], LiBF 4 [33], Zn(BF 4 ) 2 [34], Cu(BF 4 ) 2 ·xH 2 O [35], Bi(NO 3 ) 3 ·5H 2 O [36], and ZrO 2 /SO 4 2− [37] have been used as catalysts for this conversion. The reverse reaction of 1,1-diacetates to their parent aldehydes is also of practical importance, and several methods have been reported in the literature [38,39]. Many of these methods have definite draw- backs such as low yields of products, expensive and hazardous reagents, long reaction times, corrosiveness, tedious work up, and pollution problems. Heteropoly acids (HPAs) with the Keggin structure are the most studied class within polyoxometalates (POMs) because they possess relatively high thermal stability [40] and acidity [41]. Supported HPAs are important for many applications because bulk HPAs have low specific structure areas (1–10 m 2 /g). It is important to increase the surface area or even better to increase the number of accessible acid sites of the HPAs. This can be achieved by dispersing the HPAs on a solid support with a high surface area [42,43]. In a heterogeneous system, it is possible to control the solid strength by supporting HPAs on different carriers [43]. Immobilization of HPAs on a number of porous supports such as silica, active carbon, montmorillonite K-10, and zeolite [44] was therefore extensively studied. SiO 2 , which is relatively inert towards HPAs, is the most often used [45]. In a continuation of our work on the catalytic properties of heteropoly acids [46–50], we report a mild and efficient method for the preparation of 1,1-diacetates in the presence of a catalytic amount of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 (Scheme 1). Scheme 1 Catalytic synthesis of 1,1-diacetates from aldehydes over Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 under solvent-free conditions at room temperature Razieh FAZAELI et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2008, 29(1): 10–14 1 Experimental 1.1 Catalyst preparation Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 was prepared by conventional impreg- nation of SiO 2 with an aqueous solution of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 / SiO 2 , then dried at 100°C for 6 h, and calcined at 400°C for 3 h [51]. 1.2 General procedure for conversion of aldehydes to geminal diacetates A mixture of aldehyde (1 mmol), acetic anhydride (1.5 ml), and 28% Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 (0.4 g) was ground together in a mortar at room temperature for the time indicated in Table 1. The progress of the reaction was followed by thin-layer chromatography (TLC). After completion of the reaction the mixture was quenched with saturated sodium bicarbonate solution (5 ml) and extracted with ether (2×15 ml). The com- bined organic layer was dried on Na 2 SO 4 and evaporated under reduced pressure to yield pure 1,1-diacetate. 1.3 General procedure for deprotection of 1,1-diacetates A mixture of 1,1-diacetate (1 mmol) and 28% Cu 3/2 PMo 12 - O 40 /SiO 2 (0.4 g) in acetonitrile (3 ml) was stirred at room temperature for the time indicated in Table 1. After completion of the reaction (monitored by TLC or GC) the mixture was quenched with saturated sodium bicarbonate solution (5 ml) and extracted with ether (2×15 ml). The combined organic layer was dried on Na 2 SO 4 and evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by flash chromatog- raphy (eluent CCl 4 /Et 2 O, 4:1) or crystallization (n-hexane or EtOH-H 2 O) to give the corresponding aldehyde. 1.4 Selected spectroscopic data 3-Phenyl-2-propen-1,1-diol diacetate. IR (KBr): ν max = 1755, 1660, 1615, 1490, 1470, 1245, 1195, 1120, 1060, 1005, 940, 748, 690 cm –1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ): δ = 2.14 (s, 6H), 6.23 (dd, J = 16, 6.5 Hz, 1H), 6.89 (d, J = 16 Hz, 1H), 7.30–7.47 (m, 6H); 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 ): δ = 168.2, 136.4, 135.3, 128.8, 127.6, 127.0, 121.8, 89.7, 20.8. (4-Methylphenyl)methanediacetate. IR (KBr): ν max = 1765, 1750, 1230, 1205, 1070, 1005, 960, 930, 815 cm –1 ; 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ) δ = 2.16 (s, 6H), 2.41 (s, 3H), 7.26 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 7.45 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 7.69 (s, 1H); 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 ): δ = 168.6, 139.6, 132.8, 129.2, 126.6, 89.8, 21.1, 20.7. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Conversion of aldehydes to geminal diacetates Table 1 shows the effect of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 as the catalyst on the yields of aldehydes to geminal diacetates. A variety of aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes were converted to the corresponding 1,1-diacetates under solvent-free conditions using acetic anhydride in the presence of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 at room temperature with excellent yields in short reaction times. Table 1 Conversion of aldehydes to corresponding 1,1-diacetates catalyzed by Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 Forward reaction a Reverse reaction b Entry Aldehyde t/min Y c,d /% t/min Y c,d /% 1 4-Me–C 6 H 4 –CHO 7 98 4 98 2 4-NO 2 –C 6 H 4 –CHO 3 90 6 90 3 4-Cl–C 6 H 4 –CHO 6 98 8 89 4 4-OH–C 6 H 4 –CHO 5 90 10 92 5 4-OMe–C 6 H 4 –CHO 10 92 5 95 6 Ph–CH=CH–CHO 9 92 8 95 7 CH 3 –CH=CH–CHO 11 92 6 90 8 furfural 10 90 9 90 a Reaction conditions: aldehydes 1 mmol, acetic anhydride 1.5 ml, cata- lyst 0.4 g, room temperature, solvent-free. b Reaction conditions: 1,1-diacetates 1 mmol, catalyst 0.4 g, CH 3 CN 3 ml, room temperature. c All of the products were characterized by comparison of their spectral and physical data with those of authentic samples. d Isolated yields. This method was effective even with aldehydes bearing electron-withdrawing substituents, such as nitro-groups on the aromatic ring. Both activated and deactivated aromatic alde- hydes were converted to their corresponding acylals under these conditions. In the case of aliphatic aldehydes, high yields in short reaction time were also observed. Furthermore, acid sensitive aldehydes (such as furfural) and α,β-unsaturated aldehydes (such as cinnamaldehyde and crotonaldehyde) re- acted well without any decomposition or polymerization under the reaction conditions. The nature of the constituents on the aromatic ring seems to have no effect on the reaction condition. The use of just 0.4 g of 28% Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 was suffi- cient to promote the reaction, and no additives were required for this conversion. There was no improvement in the reaction rates and yields on increasing the amount of the POM from 0.4 g to 0.6 g. Under these conditions, 4-methoxybenzaldehyde as a model substrate was also used in different solvents. The results showed that the efficiency and yield of the reaction in solutions were much less than that observed under solvent-free condi- tions (Table 2). This is because the supported catalyst has a large surface area, and in solvent-free reactions, the reaction rate is a function of contact area of the starting materials. Ac- cording to the results, our method (solvent-free conditions) is suitable for the conversion of aldehydes to geminal diacetates. Razieh FAZAELI et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2008, 29(1): 10–14 2.2 Deprotection of 1,1-diacetates The 1,1-diacetates were also converted to the corresponding aldehydes using a catalytic amount of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 in CH 3 CN at room temperature (Table 1). To choose the reaction media, different solvents were investigated using the conver- sion of (4-methylphenyl)methanediacetate as a model sub- strate. Among the studied solvents, acetonitrile was the much better solvent in terms of yields (90%) than the other tested solvents such as dichloromethane (70%), tetrahydrofuran (56%), water (36%), chloroform (50%), and toluene (34%). In order to show the chemoselectivity of the method, we have performed the competitive reaction shown in Scheme 2. The results indicated that the present protocol is potentially applicable for the chemoselective conversion of aldehydes in the presence of ketone functionalities in multi-functional compounds. As shown in Scheme 2, when 4-acetylbenzalde- hyde was allowed to react with acetic anhydride under the usual conditions, only the aldehyde group reacted. Scheme 2 Competitive reaction of aldehyde and ketone using Ac 2 O in the presence of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 at room tempera- ture under solvent-free conditions 2.3 Effect of catalyst loading The effect of different Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 loadings on the cata- lytic activity after the catalyst was calcined at 400°C was in- vestigated. The results are shown in Fig. 1. There was hardly any reaction on SiO 2 . When Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 was supported on SiO 2 , the catalytic activity increased markedly with increased Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 loading, but when the loading exceeded 28%, the catalytic activity decreased. 2.4 Catalyst recovery and reusability The recovery and reusability of the supported catalyst was also investigated. We noticed that after the addition of CH 2 Cl 2 to the reaction mixture, the catalyst can be easily recovered quantitatively by simple filtration. The wet catalyst was recy- cled (the nature of the recovered catalysts has been followed by neutron activation analysis (NAA), XRD, and FT-IR spec- troscopy, and no appreciable change in activity was noticed after two cycles (Fig. 2). The products were obtained of the same purity as in the first and second runs, but the yields gradually decreased in runs carried out using a recycled cata- lyst. After the second run, the POMs were leached from the supports (shown by NAA and atomic absorption spectros- copy), and this led to the deactivation of the heterogeneous catalyst. Fig. 2 The feasibility of reusing 28% Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 in sol- vent-free conversion of aldehydes to geminal diacetates (Reaction conditions: 4-methoxybenzaldehyde 1 mmol, acetic anhy- dride 1.5 ml, catalyst 0.4 g, room temperature, solvent-free. The re- covered catalyst was washed with ethanol, dried at 100°C for 6 h, and calcined at 400°C for 3 h.) Table 2 Conversion of 4-methoxybenzaldehyde to the correspond- ing 1,1-diacetate in the presence of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 in various solvents GC yield (%) Temperature CHCl 3 CH 3 CN EtOH EtOAc EtOH Room temperature 55 68 37 43 18 50°C 72 78 55 62 51 Reaction conditions: 4-methoxybenzaldehyde 1 mmol, acetic anhydride 1.5 ml, 28% Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 0.4 g, reaction time 60 min. Fig. 1 Effect of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 loading on the performance of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 for preparation of 1,1-diacetates from aldehydes Razieh FAZAELI et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2008, 29(1): 10–14 3 Conclusions We showed an efficient and selective method for the preparation of 1,1-diacetates from aldehydes under solvent- free conditions using a catalytic amount of Keggin-type polyoxometalate. The reverse reaction of 1,1-diacetates to the corresponding aldehydes also had excellent yields when using a catalytic amount of Cu 3/2 PMo 12 O 40 /SiO 2 in CH 3 CN at room temperature. Short reaction times, excellent yields, and high chemoselectivity are the noteworthy advantages of this method. These POMs can be reused and regenerated simply by washing with ethanol and drying. coredata.dc:description: Aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes were transformed to 1,1-diacetates (acylals) under mild conditions by treatment with acetic anhydride and Cu3/2PMo12O40/SiO2 catalyst. This catalyst was efficient for the preparation of 1,1-diacetate under solvent-free conditions. The reverse reaction using the resulting 1,1-diacetate was achieved using the same catalyst in acetonitrile as a solvent. This new method has the advantages of excellent yields and short reaction time. The catalyst can be reused several times although it gets less active.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Cu3/2PMo12O40/SiO2: A Heterogeneous, Eco-friendly and Reusable Catalyst for the Solvent-Free Catalytic Preparation of 1,1-Diacetates from Aldehydes
